title: Generating Synthetic RDF Data with Connected Blank Nodes for Benchmarking

author: Christina Lantzaki, Foundation for Research and Technology - Hellas (FORTH)

segmentation: The title of the presentation is generating synthetic RDF data with connected black nodes for benchmarking.
So here is.
Outline of the presentation.
Firstly I'm going to give you some motivation and the related work.
Then I'm going to give the requirements of the generator and the component of the generator.
It follows the experimental evaluation that data sets in use and a brief conclusion.
So there are many works that deal with.
Semantic data management tasks like quitting, update, etc.
And there are many attempts to evaluate these tasks, so there are many generators in the literature that generate syntactic RDF data sets.
But the problem is that none of this data set generators thread sufficiently.
The blank node connectivity issues.
So now someone may wonder, can we simply ignore blank notes?
Well, the answer to this is that blank nodes or for short V nodes are useful because they help us to represent multi component structures like the RDF containers.
They also help us represent complex attributes like for example the address of a person and they help us apply rification so we can represent the events in the provenance chain through blank nodes.
In practice, we can see that there are many domains in the loudcloud that make use of this kind of resources, and some of them have really high percentages like those given in the box.
Moreover
There are many tasks that require we node matching.
What are these tasks?
Graph equivalence checking graph entailment that checking Delta based taurids over versions of a graph.
Synchronization of RDF data and even data integration.
So this tasks may require or become more effective when we apply over them and be node matching, But the problem is that their complexity becomes dependent on blank nodes and how they are connected.
So imagine that for very complex B node structures, these tasks become intractable.
Actually, all of them are belonging to the NP class.
So the main research direction is to construct algorithms that just approximate the optimal solution.
Here is a simple example where we try to see if our graphs are equivalent.
So if we do not apply any be node matching then the blank nodes are considered different even if they have the same identifier.
But if we apply be not matching.
So here if we must blank node run with blank node 2, then we see that the graphs are equivalent.
So this is justice.
Case, but imagine that we have more more blank blank nodes in its graph, so more combinations to be checked by the system, and we also have connections between these blank nodes.
So again, someone may wonder, are these complex structures appearing in public data?
Well, according to the literature, the 1.6% of the structures are cyclic.
That means that they are complex and some of them have a high tree.
With that means that they are even more complex.
We have also queried the loudcloud and point and we found out that 30,000 of blank nodes participate in cycles.

Now that's why I understand that there is a need for this for this algorithm to exist, and there is a need for a common evaluation, so that's why we designed and implemented the generator called Beats, and that allows building data sets with blank nodes and that offers control over their connectivity.
So.
Here is the related work.
There are many notable generators in the bibliography, so the generator of the LBM aims at benchmarking systems with respect to use in all applications.
So here the the context is different and the generator has different requirements.
We have the generator of the Berlin benchmark that supports the creation of large data sets, but they do not control the way the resources are connected between them.
And we have the generator of the Social intelligence benchmark that is closer to our generator because they generate social graphs that contain cetera.
Saying certain structural correlations, so even if they try to control the the connection, we do it in a more.
In the closer way to what we want, and we are also take into account the blank node connectivity issues.
So here are the requirements of the generator.
Firstly, we want to ensure the correlation of data.
So in order to control the structure and This is why we adopt A specific real world like schema.
Secondly, we want to ensure the scaling of data so as to see how scalable the works are and regarding the anonymous resources we want to control the way the blank nodes are connected between them.
But also we want to control how blank nodes are connected with the named resources.
These two last requirements are satisfied by a variety of features that we're going to describe later.
So here is the schema that our generator uses.
As you can see, this is a simple schema of a social network, so the social network can have one more members of the persons and each person can have its personal information.
It can also have which is described through its center, the name, the address and the security mode.
The person can also have one or more activities and one or more public messages.
As you can see here, the person can be connected with more persons through the House, friend and parent of properties.
So he.
Here is a an instance over our schema of one person.
Let me note that the social network is always represented as a UI and the persons are always represented as black nodes.
So here is a person that is member of the social net one and here is its personal information which is also represented as a blank node.
This is optional, but it is quite reasonable to happen becausw this kind of resource.
It's just an auxiliary node that will help us to connect this this person with a variety of complex attributes.
So these attributes are the name, the gender, the birthday, the address and the security mode.
As you can see, the address is also represented as a blank node for the same reason.
Now this person has also an activity and a public message which is described through its date and its content.
So here we are, tried and made a person with four blank nodes.
And the number of pairs on the number of blank nodes and the number of your eyes that each person has is controlled through the parameters that you see on the top there be pair and you pair.
We have also two paths or blank nodes.

Here the logging longest path has length two and this is actually the longest path that we can manage inside one person because the resources of the activity and city are always represented as your eyes.
So when we separated the person into two parts that isolated part with is called like this big cause it cannot connect these four blank nodes with more black nodes.
So it's A kind of isolation.

And we also have the connection part which contains the has friend, sibling or parent of properties that give us the ability to connect this person with more persons and in this way to connect directly be node structures.
OK, so here are some blank nodes.
Imagine that all of them are persons and here is is an example of how they could be connected through their connection parts.
So now I also note that the has friend parent, often sibling of relations are nonsymmetric, as you can see in the example too.
So now we're ready to define what a big component is.
Imagine the baby trip as a triple that contains 2 blank nodes and the big component is defined as the maximal set of baby triples of connected baby triples in RDF graph.
The so for this example, imagine that all these persons are members of the same social network.
So this is our graph Z and according to the definition we have two big components, the BC one and BC 2.
Now, the challenge that we had found counter was how to control the complexity of this big component.
That's why we propose a combination of features which are the morphology, the average clustering coefficient, the density, and the similarity mode.
Now, regarding the morphology.
It actually controls how the persons are connected between them through the has friend property.
So it is a qualitative parameter and it has four categories, the single where we have a single person that is not connected with no friends.
The tree where the persons form directed tree structure.
The dog where they form a directed acyclic graph and the graph where they perform a graph with directed cycles as in the example.

As a refinement parameter over the morphology, we propose the average clustering coefficient, which is actually the average of the local clustering coefficient of the persons inside the big component.
This metric comes from the social network analysis field and it actually in our case count how the friends of our person are friends between them.
So here is the formula.
And this is a simple example where we have we want to check the how the French of the blue node are connected between them so.
So the friends are the Red Note and as you can see here, they only have one ads, so they're not fully connect.
But with two edges, we have a complete graph between these two red nodes, so full connection and the clustering coefficient of the blue node is now equal to 1.
The maximum.
If this is the French were three, so the two edges weren't enough for a complete graph, we have to get six edges between these friends in order to make a complete graph full connection.
And again, clustering coefficient equals one.
Now this is for our case an example where.
The local clustering coefficient of the blue node on the right is equal to 1.
Because you see a full connection between the friends for the node on the left, we have one edge, so it's 0.5 and for the node on the top we have against 0.5.
So the average clustering coefficient equal to 0.66.
Now, because we wanted to add realism to our data sets, we decided to enable more relations between the persons.
So we have also parent, often sibling of properties and the metric that counter the number of these properties is the density.
Here is the formula.
And here is a simple example where as you can see we have two siblings, often two parents of properties.
So the density comes to 0.66.
Now, apart from controlling the complexity inside the big component, the blank nodes we also wanted to control how blank nodes are connected to the named resources.
So that's why we introduced the similarity modes metric that it provides us the ability to make the name named resources of the persons as similar as possible.
How, by turning more your eyes to blank nodes and by converting the rest of EU arise and literals by making them.
As similar as possible.
We have 3 scales of similarity.
There is a medium and hard and as the similarity mode scales up, the similarity between the persons becomes higher and the blank node matching becomes harder.
So here are the main input parameters, so.

For the generator, the number of resources, the number of persons, the number of components, the range of the diameters, a subset for the morphologies, and two modes want to distribute the big components to the morphologies and want to distribute the persons to the big components.
But it has OK.
It has many options like uniform power law etc.
We also.
Will give her some extra.
Parameters which enable the user to have full control over the complexity of these components.
The range of the clustering coefficient density, and the similarity mode.
Here are the faces of the generator, the preparation phase, the instance generation, and the connection phase.
In the preparation phase we give us input the input parameters and we get us out with a table with the features of its big component.
In vain, so generation phase would take this table with the features and we create for each tuple for its big component that ripples of the specific component.
In the connection phase we have this big components and we connect connect them under the same social network.
So here is our graph.

Now, regarding the experimental evaluation, we had to investigate the efficiency of the generator as regards the number of resources and the complexity of the big component, and we also used the data sets to see how well they capture the complexity that is crucial for our algorithms.
So here, as you can see, the algorithm has linear increase in time regarding the number of resources.
Um, regarding the.
The complex is the scaling up of the complexity of the big components.
We have three complexity levels where we scale up the values of the complexity parameters.
And.
Here, as you can see, there is again a linear increase in the total generation time.
So the main point.
Is that there is no restriction factor regarding time.
The only restriction factor has to do with the data structure that temporarily stores the has print properties.
So here is a worst case scenario where the space complexity may become quadratic to the number of persons.

Now another important issue is that we had to evaluate how the algorithms that been automatic algorithm deviate from the optimal solution when they are used over our data sets that generated data sets.

So we evaluated the signature algorithm, which actually is an approximation algorithm that matches the blank nodes between two graphs so as to reduce the change operations that are needed in order to go from the one graph to the other.
We compare its graph to itself, so the optimal solution solution is 0 change operations.
And.
Here is the result.
As you can see for the easy similarity mode at, the algorithm manages to find the optimal solution for all the range of the clustering coefficient going to the medium similarity mode.
We have higher deviation from the optimal and going to the hard.
We have an even higher deviation, so we understand that there is this metric is a good way to understand how would deviate from the optimal.
The same.
As for the clustering coefficient, because as you can see we increase the clustering coefficient and the deviation also increases.
Are sold.
Result is that the the summary is that the generated data sets succeed in making clear how the approximate solutions deviate from the optimal ones.
As a conclusion, which then is the first semantic web data generator that creates data set with blank nodes and offers control over their connectivity.

It manages it through a plethora of configuration parameters and it has linear time requirements and usually special, and it succeeds in capturing the complexity that is crucial for the valuated tasks.
